column1: The first boardwalk was built in 1870 along a portion of the beach in an effort to help hotel owners keep sand out of their lobbies. Businesses were restricted and the boardwalk was removed each year at the end of the peak season. Because of its effectiveness and popularity
column2: the boardwalk was expanded in length and width
column3: and modified several times in subsequent years. The historic length of the boardwalk
column4: before the destructive 1944 Great Atlantic Hurricane
column5: was about 7 miles (11 km) and it extended from Atlantic City to Longport
column6: through Ventnor and Margate.The first road connecting the city to the mainland at Pleasantville was completed in 1870 and charged a 30-cent toll. Albany Avenue was the first road to the mainland available without a toll.By 1878

column1: In the early part of the 20th century
column2: Atlantic City went through a radical building boom. Many of the modest boarding houses that dotted the boardwalk were replaced with large hotels. Two of the city's most distinctive hotels were the Marlborough-Blenheim Hotel and the Traymore Hotel.
Josiah White III bought a parcel of land near Ohio Avenue and the boardwalk and built the Queen Anne style Marlborough House. The hotel was a success and
column4: he chose to expand the hotel and bought another parcel of land adjacent to his Marlborough House. In an effort to make his new hotel a source of conversation
column5: White hired the architectural firm of Price and McLanahan. The firm made use of reinforced concrete
column6: a new building material invented by Jean-Louis Lambot in 1848 (Joseph Monier received the patent in 1867). The hotel's Spanish and Moorish themes
column7: capped off with its signature dome and chimneys
column8: represented a step forward from other hotels that had a classically designed influence. White named the new hotel the Blenheim and merged the two hotels into the Marlborough-Blenheim. Bally's Atlantic City was later constructed at this location.

column1: The Traymore Hotel was located at the corner of Illinois Avenue and the boardwalk. Begun in 1879 as a small boarding house
column2: the hotel grew through a series of uncoordinated expansions. By 1914

column6: commissioned the firm of Price and McLanahan to build an even bigger hotel. Rising 16 stories
column7: the tan brick and gold-capped hotel would become one of the city's best-known landmarks. The hotel made use of ocean-facing hotel rooms by jutting its wings farther from the main portion of the hotel along Pacific Avenue.

column1: Like many older east coast cities after World War II
column2: Atlantic City became plagued with poverty
column3: crime
column5: and general economic decline in the mid-to-late 20th century. The neighborhood known as the "Inlet" became particularly impoverished. The reasons for the resort's decline were multi-layered. First
column6: the automobile became more readily available to many Americans after the war. Atlantic City had initially relied upon visitors coming by train and staying for a couple of weeks. The car allowed them to come and go as they pleased
column7: and many people would spend only a few days
column8: rather than weeks. The advent of suburbia also played a significant role. With many families moving to their own private houses
column9: luxuries such as home air conditioning and swimming pools diminished their interest in flocking to the luxury beach resorts during the hot summer. Finally
column10: the rise of relatively cheap jet airline service allowed visitors to travel to year-round resort cities such as Miami Beach and the Bahamas.

column1: In an effort at revitalizing the city
column2: New Jersey voters in 1976 passed a referendum
column3: approving casino gambling for Atlantic City; this came after a 1974 referendum on legalized gambling failed to pass. Immediately after the legislation passed
column4: the owners of the Chalfonte-Haddon Hall Hotel began converting it into the Resorts International. It was the first legal casino in the eastern United States when it opened on May 26
column5: 1978. Other casinos were soon constructed along the Boardwalk and
column6: later
column7: in the marina district for a total of eleven today. The introduction of gambling did not
column8: however
column9: quickly eliminate many of the urban problems that plagued Atlantic City. Many people have suggested that it only served to exacerbate those problems
column10: as attested to by the stark contrast between tourism intensive areas and the adjacent impoverished working-class neighborhoods. In addition
column11: Atlantic City has been less popular than Las Vegas as a gambling city in the United States. Donald Trump helped bring big name boxing bouts to the city to attract customers to his casinos. The boxer Mike Tyson had most of his fights in Atlantic City in the 1980s
column12: which helped Atlantic City achieve nationwide attention as a gambling resort. Numerous highrise condominiums were built for use as permanent residences or second homes. By end of the decade it was one of the most popular tourist destinations in the United States.

column3: the Supreme Court agreed to hear Christie v. National Collegiate Athletic Association and heard oral arguments in December 2017. Then

column1: Despite being the state to initiate the landmark ruling

column1: With the redevelopment of the Las Vegas Strip and the opening of Foxwoods Resort Casino and Mohegan Sun in Connecticut in the early 1990s
column2: along with newly built casinos in the nearby Philadelphia metro area in the 2000s
column3: Atlantic City's tourism began to decline due to its failure to diversify away from gaming. Determined to expand
column4: in 1999 the Atlantic City Redevelopment Authority partnered with Las Vegas casino mogul Steve Wynn to develop a new roadway to a barren section of the city near the Marina. Nicknamed "The Tunnel Project"
column5: Steve Wynn planned the proposed 'Mirage Atlantic City' around the idea that he would connect the $330 million tunnel stretching 2.5 miles (4.0 km) from the Atlantic City Expressway to his new resort. The roadway was later officially named the Atlantic City-Brigantine Connector
column6: and funnels incoming traffic off of the expressway into the city's marina district and the city of Brigantine.Although Wynn's plans for development in the city were scrapped in 2002
column7: the tunnel opened in 2001. The new roadway prompted Boyd Gaming in partnership with MGM/Mirage to build Atlantic City's newest casino. The Borgata opened in July 2003
column8: and its success brought an influx of developers to Atlantic City with plans for building grand Las Vegas style mega casinos to revitalize the aging city.Owing to economic conditions and the late 2000s recession

column10: who purchased the Sands Atlantic City for $250-$270 million
column11: closed it on November 11
column13: with plans to replace it with a larger casino.  The following year

column15: Las Vegas styled implosion

column18: effectively ending their plans for the MGM Grand Atlantic City.In 2006

column26: Revel had completed all of the exterior work and had continued work on the interior after finally receiving the funding necessary to complete construction. It had a soft opening in April 2012
column27: and was fully open by May 2012. Ten months later

column35: and reopened in 2018.In the wake of the closures and declining revenue from casinos

With casino revenue declining from $5.2 billion in 2006 to $2.9 billion in 2013

column1: According to the Köppen climate classification system
column2: Atlantic City
column3: New Jersey has a humid subtropical climate (Cfa) with warm
column5: cool winters and year-around precipitation. Cfa climates are characterized by all months having an average mean temperature > 32 °F (> 0 °C)
column6: at least four months with an average mean temperature ≥ 50 °F (≥ 10 °C)
column7: at least one month with an average mean temperature ≥ 72 °F (≥ 22 °C) and no significant precipitation difference between seasons. During the summer months in Atlantic City
column8: a cooling afternoon sea breeze is present on most days
column9: but episodes of extreme heat and humidity can occur with heat index values ≥ 95 °F (≥ 35 °C). During the winter months
column10: episodes of extreme cold and wind can occur with wind chill values < 0 °F (< -18 °C). The plant hardiness zone at Atlantic City Beach is 7b with an average annual extreme minimum air temperature of 9 °F (-13 °C). The average seasonal (November–April) snowfall total is 12 to 18 inches (300 to 460 mm)
column11: and the average snowiest month is February which corresponds with the annual peak in nor'easter activity.

column1: Ever since Atlantic City's growth as a resort town
column2: numerous attractions and tourist traps have originated in the city. A popular fixture in the early 20th century at the Steel Pier was horse diving
column3: which was introduced by William "Doc" Carver. The Steel Pier featured several other novelty attractions
column5: human high-divers and a water circus. Advertisements for the Steel Pier in its heyday featured plaster sculptures set upon wooden bases along roads leading up to Atlantic City. By the end of World War II
column6: many animal demonstrations declined in popularity after criticisms of animal abuse and neglect.

It is the tallest lighthouse in the state of New Jersey and is the third tallest masonry lighthouse in the United States. Construction began in 1854

column16: Lucy the Elephant has become almost an icon for the Atlantic City area. Lucy is a six-story elephant-shaped example of novelty architecture
column17: constructed of wood and tin sheeting in 1882 by James V. Lafferty in an effort to sell real estate and attract tourism. Over the years
column18: Lucy had served as a restaurant
column21: and tavern (the last closed by Prohibition). Lucy had fallen into disrepair by the 1960s and was scheduled for demolition. The structure was moved and refurbished as a result of a "Save Lucy" campaign in 1970 and received designation as a National Historic Landmark in 1976
column22: and is open as a museum.

column1: Atlantic City is the home of the Miss America competition
column2: however it was moved to Las Vegas for seven years before returning. The Miss America competition originated on September 7
column5: and it included state contestants as well as women from various cities around the country. The event that year was called the "Atlantic City Pageant"
column6: and the winner of the grand prize
column7: Margaret Gorman
column8: took home the 3-foot Golden Mermaid trophy. Gorman was not called "Miss America" until 1922
column9: when she re-entered the pageant and lost to Mary Campbell. The pageant was initiated to extend the tourist season after the Labor Day weekend. The pageant has been nationally televised since 1954. It peaked in the early 1960s
column10: when it was repeatedly the highest-rated program on American television. It was seen as a symbol of the United States
column11: with Miss America often being referred to as the female equivalent of the President. The pageant's longtime emcee

column15: sensors activate a recorded playback of his "There She Is..." line through speakers hidden behind nearby bushes.An LGBT event known as the "Miss'd America Pageant" is held annually. Originally started in 1994 as a fundraiser for local LGBT charities

column1: Atlantic City is governed within the Faulkner Act (formally known as the Optional Municipal Charter Law) under the Mayor-Council system of municipal government (Plan D)
column2: implemented by direct petition effective as of July 1
column3: 1982. The city is one of 71 municipalities (of the 565) statewide governed under this form. The governing body of Atlantic City is the Mayor and the City Council
column4: all elected on a partisan basis to serve four-year terms of office as part of the November general election. The council is comprised of nine members
column5: who are elected on a staggered basis
column6: with one member from each of six wards and three serving at-large. The six ward seats are up for election together and the mayoral seat and the council at-large seats are up for vote together two years later. The City Council exercises the legislative power of the municipality for the purpose of holding Council meetings to introduce ordinances and resolutions to regulate City government. In addition
column7: Council members review budgets submitted by the Mayor; provide for an annual audit of the city's accounts and financial transactions; organize standing committees and hold public hearings to address important issues which impact Atlantic City. Former Mayor Bob Levy created the Atlantic City Ethics Board in 2007
column8: but the Board was dissolved two years later by vote of the Atlantic City Council.

column23: LaToya Dunston was selected from a list of three candidates nominated by the Democratic municipal committee to serve the remainder of the term of the Second Ward seat that had been held by Marty Small until he stepped down when he was appointed as mayor. In January 2020
column24: Dunston was appointed to fill the Second Ward seat expiring in December 2023 that Small had won in November 2019 but declined to fill; Dunston will serve on an interim basis until the November 2020 general election
column25: when voters will select a candidate to serve the balance of the term of office.

column1: The New Jersey Casino Control Commission is a New Jersey state governmental agency that was founded in 1977 as the state's Gaming Control Board
column2: responsible for administering the Casino Control Act and its regulations to assure public trust and confidence in the credibility and integrity of the casino industry and casino operations in Atlantic City. Casinos operate under licenses granted by the commission. The commission is headquartered in the Arcade Building at Tennessee Avenue and Boardwalk in Atlantic City.

column1: ==== New Jersey Division of Gaming Enforcement ====
The New Jersey Division of Gaming Enforcement is a division of the New Jersey Department of Law and Public Safety and is responsible for certifying casino gaming revenue
column2: registering casino employees and non-gaming vendors
column3: licensing gaming vendors
column4: and handling all casino patron complaints.

column1: The CRDA was founded in 1984 and is responsible for directing the spending of casino reinvestment funds in public and private projects to benefit Atlantic City and other areas of the state. From 1985 through April 2008
column2: CRDA spent US$1.5 billion on projects in Atlantic City and US$300 million throughout New Jersey.

column1: ==== Atlantic City Convention and Visitors Authority ====

The Convention & Visitors Authority (ACCVA) was in charge of advertising and marketing for the city as well as promoting economic growth through convention and leisure tourism development. The ACCVA managed the Boardwalk Hall and Atlantic City Convention Center
column2: as well as the Boardwalk Welcome Center inside Boardwalk Hall and a welcome center on the Atlantic City Expressway. In 2011
column3: the ACCVA was absorbed into the CRDA as part of the state takeover that created the tourism district.

column1: The Atlantic City Special Improvement District (SID) was a nonprofit organization created in 1992
column2: funded by a special assessment tax on businesses within the improvement district. It carried out various activities to improve the city's business community
column3: including street cleaning and promotional efforts. In 2011
column4: the SID was absorbed by the CRDA; the former SID boundaries would be expanded to the include all areas in the newly formed tourism district. Under the new structure
column5: established by state legislation
column6: the CRDA assumed responsibility for the staff
column7: equipment and programs of the SID. The new SID division includes a SID committee made up of CRDA board members and an advisory council consisting of the current trustees and others.

column1: The Atlantic City Fire Department (ACFD) provides fire protection and first responder emergency medical services to the city. The ACFD operates out of six fire stations
column2: located throughout the city in one battalion
column3: under the command of a Battalion Chief
column4: who in-turn reports to an on-duty Deputy Chief
column5: or Tour Commander each shift.

column1: The city is protected by the Atlantic City Police Department
column2: which handles 150
column3: 000 calls per year. The Chief of Police is Henry White.

column1: Commercial airlines serve Atlantic City via Atlantic City International Airport

column1: Atlantic City International Airport is a focus city for Spirit Airlines. The airport is also served by various scheduled chartered flight companies.
The AtlantiCare Regional Medical Center is a health system based in Atlantic City. Founded in 1898

column3: New Jersey. It has Atlantic City's only cancer institute
column5: and neonatal intensive care unit.
